content.text:
Section 1: Short title, extent and commencement

(1) This Act may be called the Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023.

(2) The provisions of this Sanhita, other than those relating to Chapters IX, XI and XII thereof, shall not apply---
(a) to the State of Nagaland;
(b) to the tribal areas,
but the concerned State Government may, by notification, apply such provisions or any of them to the whole or part of the State of Nagaland or such tribal areas, as the case may be, with such supplemental, incidental or consequential modifications, as may be specified in the notification.

Explanation.---In this section, 'tribal areas' means the territories which immediately before the 21st day of January, 1972, were included in the tribal areas of Assam, as referred to in paragraph 20 of the Sixth Schedule to the Constitution, other than those within the local limits of the municipality of Shillong.

(3) It shall come into force on such date as the Central Government may, by notification in the Official Gazette, appoint.

Footnote: 1st July, 2024, [except the provisions of the entry relation to Section 106(2) in the first Schedule], vide notification No. S.O. 848(E), dated, 23rd day of February, 2024, see Gazette of India, Extraordinary, Part II, sec. 3(ii).

CONCEPT:

Section 1 embodies three foundational legal concepts:

1. Nomenclature (Naming): Every statute must have an official short title for identification and citation in legal proceedings. This provides legal certainty and eliminates ambiguity.

2. Territorial Jurisdiction: The extent clause defines where a law applies geographically. Special provisions recognize constitutional protections for tribal areas and special category states, balancing national uniformity with regional autonomy.

3. Commencement: Laws don't automatically take effect upon passage. The commencement clause allows time for implementation, training, and awareness. This concept of 'appointed day' gives flexibility to the executive.

Together, these concepts establish the legal identity, scope, and timeline of the entire statute.

EXAMPLES:

Example 1 - Nomenclature in Court:
A lawyer files a bail application and cites 'Section 479, BNSS'. The judge immediately understands this refers to the Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023, not CrPC. The short title in Section 1(1) enables precise legal citation.

Example 2 - Territorial Exemption:
Police in Kohima, Nagaland arrest someone in June 2024. They cannot use provisions from Chapter V (about arrest procedures) because Section 1(2)(a) exempts Nagaland from most BNSS provisions. They continue using CrPC until the Nagaland Government issues a notification adopting BNSS.

Example 3 - Commencement Date:
A crime occurs on June 30, 2024 at 11:30 PM in Delhi. Investigation begins July 1, 2024. Per Section 1(3), BNSS came into force on July 1, 2024. Therefore, the investigation follows BNSS procedures, not CrPC (which was repealed), even though the crime occurred under the old law.

Example 4 - State Notification:
Nagaland Government decides to adopt BNSS provisions on community service (Chapter XI). They issue a notification under Section 1(2) applying only Chapter XI with modifications for local customs. Now community service provisions apply in Nagaland, but other BNSS chapters still don't.

The bare act of Section 1 contains three subsections: (1) Declares the official name 'Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023', (2) Provides exemptions for Nagaland and tribal areas from most provisions except Chapters IX, XI, XII, and (3) States the commencement date to be notified by Central Government. Example: This is the complete legal text as enacted by Parliament.

The bare act text is important because it provides the exact legal language used in the statute. Courts and legal professionals rely on this precise wording for interpretation and application. Example: Like reading the original Constitution rather than a summary - the exact words matter in law.

This bare act text appears at the very beginning of the Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023. It is Section 1 of the Act, found in the official gazette notification. Example: Located on the first pages of the official BNSS publication.

Section 1 was enacted in 2023 as part of BNSS. Subsection (3) states the Act came into force on 1st July, 2024, as notified by the Central Government. Example: The law was passed in 2023 but became operational from July 1, 2024.

This is Section 1 of BNSS 2023, titled 'Short title, extent and commencement'. It is the foundational section containing three subsections that establish the law's identity, territorial extent, and effective date. Example: Among all sections of BNSS, this is the introductory section that sets the stage.

Section 1 operates through three mechanisms: (1) Subsection-1 declares the name declaratively, (2) Subsection-2 creates exemptions with flexibility for State Governments to apply provisions through notification, (3) Subsection-3 delegates commencement power to Central Government. Example: It establishes identity, scope, and timing all in one section.

mcq_pool.question: How many subsections does Section 1 contain?
mcq_pool.explanation: Section 1 contains three subsections numbered (1), (2), and (3).

mcq_pool.question: When did BNSS 2023 come into force?
mcq_pool.explanation: BNSS came into force on 1st July, 2024 as per the footnote.

mcq_pool.question: What date is mentioned in the Explanation regarding tribal areas?
mcq_pool.explanation: The Explanation refers to 21st January, 1972 for defining tribal areas.

mcq_pool.question: Which municipality is excluded from the tribal areas definition?
mcq_pool.explanation: The municipality of Shillong is excluded from the tribal areas definition.

mcq_pool.question: Who appoints the commencement date of the Act?
mcq_pool.explanation: The Central Government appoints the commencement date by notification.

mcq_pool.question: The notification number for commencement was:
mcq_pool.explanation: The notification number was S.O. 848(E).

mcq_pool.question: Which provision was excepted from commencement on 1st July 2024?
mcq_pool.explanation: Provisions relating to Section 106(2) in the first Schedule were excepted.

mcq_pool.question: Tribal areas referred to paragraph 20 of which Schedule?
mcq_pool.explanation: It refers to the Sixth Schedule to the Constitution.

mcq_pool.question: The notification date was:
mcq_pool.explanation: The notification was dated 23rd day of February, 2024.

mcq_pool.question: Where was the notification published?
mcq_pool.explanation: It was published in the Official Gazette of India, Extraordinary, Part II, sec. 3(ii).

mcq_pool.question: Which state of India is specifically mentioned by name in Section 1(2)?
mcq_pool.explanation: Nagaland is specifically mentioned in Section 1(2)(a).

mcq_pool.question: The word 'Sanhita' in the bare act means:
mcq_pool.explanation: Sanhita translates to Code.

mcq_pool.question: How many chapters are mentioned as applicable to exempt areas?
mcq_pool.explanation: Three chapters (IX, XI, and XII) are mentioned.

mcq_pool.question: The bare act includes how many explanations?
mcq_pool.explanation: There is one Explanation after Subsection (2).

mcq_pool.question: Tribal areas were previously part of which state?
mcq_pool.explanation: They were included in the tribal areas of Assam.

mcq_pool.question: What type of modifications can State Government specify?
mcq_pool.explanation: Supplemental, incidental, or consequential modifications can be specified.

mcq_pool.question: The title of Section 1 is:
mcq_pool.explanation: The title is 'Short title, extent and commencement'.

mcq_pool.question: The bare act uses 'may be called' in which subsection?
mcq_pool.explanation: Subsection (1) states 'may be called'.

mcq_pool.question: How many footnotes are included in Section 1?
mcq_pool.explanation: There is one footnote about the commencement date.

mcq_pool.question: The phrase 'as the case may be' appears in which subsection?
mcq_pool.explanation: It appears in Subsection (2).

truefalse_pool.explanation: Yes, it has subsections (1), (2), and (3).

truefalse_pool.statement: BNSS came into force on 1st January 2024.
truefalse_pool.explanation: It came into force on 1st July 2024.

truefalse_pool.statement: Shillong municipality is excluded from tribal areas definition.
truefalse_pool.explanation: Correct. The Explanation specifically excludes Shillong municipality.

truefalse_pool.statement: State Government appoints the commencement date.
truefalse_pool.explanation: Central Government appoints the commencement date.

truefalse_pool.statement: The Explanation refers to 21st January 1972.
truefalse_pool.explanation: Yes, this date is mentioned in the Explanation.

truefalse_pool.statement: Nagaland is specifically mentioned in Section 1.
truefalse_pool.explanation: Nagaland is mentioned in Subsection (2)(a).

truefalse_pool.statement: Section 106(2) came into force on 1st July 2024.
truefalse_pool.explanation: Provisions relating to Section 106(2) were excepted from commencement.

truefalse_pool.statement: The notification was published in Official Gazette.
truefalse_pool.explanation: Yes, it was published in the Official Gazette of India.

truefalse_pool.statement: Section 1 has no Explanation.
truefalse_pool.explanation: There is one Explanation in Section 1.

truefalse_pool.statement: Chapters IX, XI, and XII apply to exempt areas.
truefalse_pool.explanation: Correct. These three chapters apply to Nagaland and tribal areas.

truefalse_pool.statement: Tribal areas referred to the Fifth Schedule.
truefalse_pool.explanation: They refer to paragraph 20 of the Sixth Schedule.

truefalse_pool.statement: The notification number was S.O. 848(E).
truefalse_pool.explanation: Yes, this is the correct notification number.

truefalse_pool.statement: Section 1 is titled 'Name of the Act'.
truefalse_pool.explanation: It's titled 'Short title, extent and commencement'.

truefalse_pool.statement: The notification was dated 23rd February 2024.
truefalse_pool.explanation: Yes, this is the correct date.

truefalse_pool.statement: Only Central Government can apply provisions to exempt areas.
truefalse_pool.explanation: The concerned State Government can apply provisions.

truefalse_pool.statement: The bare act includes footnotes.
truefalse_pool.explanation: Yes, there is a footnote about the commencement date.

truefalse_pool.statement: Tribal areas were part of Bengal before 1972.
truefalse_pool.explanation: They were part of Assam, not Bengal.

truefalse_pool.statement: State Government can make consequential modifications.
truefalse_pool.explanation: Yes, supplemental, incidental, or consequential modifications are allowed.

truefalse_pool.statement: The Act was called BNSS 2024.
truefalse_pool.explanation: It's called BNSS 2023.

truefalse_pool.statement: The bare act is the exact legal text as enacted.
truefalse_pool.explanation: Yes, bare act refers to the original statutory text.

content.text:
Subsection-1: Law's Official Name

• This law is called the 'Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023'.
• The complete title establishes the legal identity of this code.
• It consists of four Hindi words followed by the year 2023.

Concept with Example - Subsection 1:

Concept 1: Law's Name (कानून का नाम)
This law is called the 'Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023'.
यह कानून 'भारतीय नागरिक सुरक्षा संहिता, 2023' कहलाता है।
• Example (उदाहरण): Just like your name is Raj or Priya, this law's name is BNSS, 2023.
जैसे आपका नाम राज या प्रिया है, वैसे ही इस कानून का नाम BNSS, 2023 है।

Concept 2: English Translation (अंग्रेजी अनुवाद)
In English, it means 'Indian Citizen Security Code, 2023'.
अंग्रेजी में, इसका अर्थ है 'इंडियन सिटीजन सिक्योरिटी कोड, 2023'।
• Example (उदाहरण): Like 'Vidyalaya' means 'School' in English, BNSS means 'Indian Citizen Security Code'.
जैसे 'विद्यालय' का अंग्रेजी में मतलब 'स्कूल' होता है, वैसे ही BNSS का मतलब 'इंडियन सिटीजन सिक्योरिटी कोड' है।
Subsection-1 states: This law is officially called 'Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023'. Example: Just like saying 'My name is John' - this subsection declares the law's official name.

Subsection-1 exists to officially declare the law's name for legal recognition. Without this subsection, the law would have no formal identity. Example: Like a birth certificate that officially names a child, this subsection officially names the law.

Subsection-1 appears at the very beginning of the BNSS 2023 document. It is the first subsection of Section 1. Example: Found on the opening page of the official BNSS text, before any other provisions.

Subsection-1 came into effect in 2023 when the law was enacted. This naming provision became official with the passage of the Act. Example: Since 2023, this subsection has been the legal reference point for the law's name.
Subsection-1 is the naming clause of BNSS 2023. It is the first and foundational subsection of Section 1. Example: Among all subsections, this is the one that specifically addresses the law's title.

Subsection-1 works by providing a simple declarative statement: 'This law is called...'
It establishes legal nomenclature through direct declaration. Example: Legal professionals cite this subsection when referencing the law's official name in documents.

mcq_pool.question: What is this law called?
mcq_pool.explanation: The law is officially called 'Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023'.

mcq_pool.question: In which year was this law named?
mcq_pool.explanation: The law was named in the year 2023.

mcq_pool.question: The term 'Bharatiya' in the law's name means:
mcq_pool.explanation: 'Bharatiya' means 'Indian' in English.

mcq_pool.question: What does 'Nagarik' mean in English?
mcq_pool.explanation: 'Nagarik' translates to 'Citizen' in English.

mcq_pool.question: The word 'Suraksha' in the title means:
mcq_pool.explanation: 'Suraksha' means 'Security' or 'Protection'.

mcq_pool.question: 'Sanhita' in the law's name translates to:
mcq_pool.explanation: 'Sanhita' means 'Code' in English.

mcq_pool.question: How many words are in the law's name (excluding the year)?
mcq_pool.explanation: There are four words: Bharatiya, Nagarik, Suraksha, Sanhita.

mcq_pool.question: The short form of this law is:
mcq_pool.explanation: The short form is BNSS (Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita).

mcq_pool.question: This law is related to:
mcq_pool.explanation: The law is about Citizen Security (Nagarik Suraksha).

mcq_pool.question: The complete title includes which year?
mcq_pool.explanation: The complete title includes the year 2023.

mcq_pool.question: Which language is the law's name in?
mcq_pool.explanation: The law's name is in Hindi.

mcq_pool.question: The first word in the law's name is:
mcq_pool.explanation: The first word is 'Bharatiya'.

mcq_pool.question: The last word before the year is:
mcq_pool.explanation: The last word before 2023 is 'Sanhita'.

mcq_pool.question: This law is also known as:
mcq_pool.explanation: It's commonly abbreviated as BNSS.

mcq_pool.question: The law's title contains how many numbers?
mcq_pool.explanation: The title contains one number: 2023.

mcq_pool.question: What type of document is this?
mcq_pool.explanation: It's a Law/Code (Sanhita).

mcq_pool.question: The second word in the law's name is:
mcq_pool.explanation: The second word is 'Nagarik'.

mcq_pool.question: The third word in the law's name is:
mcq_pool.explanation: The third word is 'Suraksha'.

mcq_pool.question: This law is meant for:
mcq_pool.explanation: It's for all Indian citizens (Bharatiya Nagarik).

mcq_pool.question: The year 2023 appears at the:
mcq_pool.explanation: The year 2023 appears at the end of the title.

truefalse_pool.explanation: This is the exact official name of the law.

truefalse_pool.explanation: BNSS is the correct abbreviation.

truefalse_pool.explanation: 'Nagarik' means 'Citizen', not 'Police'.

truefalse_pool.explanation: This is the correct meaning of 'Suraksha'.

truefalse_pool.statement: The law was enacted in 2020.

truefalse_pool.explanation: 'Sanhita' means 'Code'.

truefalse_pool.explanation: It contains four words plus the year.

truefalse_pool.statement: The law's name begins with 'Bharatiya'.
truefalse_pool.explanation: 'Bharatiya' is the first word.

truefalse_pool.statement: This is a law about traffic regulations.
truefalse_pool.explanation: It's about citizen security, not traffic.

truefalse_pool.statement: The law's title ends with the year 2023.
truefalse_pool.explanation: The title ends with 2023.

truefalse_pool.statement: 'Bharatiya' means 'British' in English.
truefalse_pool.explanation: 'Bharatiya' means 'Indian', not 'British'.

truefalse_pool.statement: This law is called a 'Sanhita' (Code).
truefalse_pool.explanation: Yes, it's officially called a Sanhita.

truefalse_pool.statement: The law has no year mentioned in its title.
truefalse_pool.explanation: The year 2023 is mentioned in the title.

subsection_2.title: Special Provisions for Nagaland and Tribal Areas

content.text:
Subsection-2: Special Provisions for Nagaland and Tribal Areas

• This subsection exempts Nagaland and tribal areas from most provisions of BNSS.
• Only Chapters IX, XI, and XII apply to these areas by default.
• State Governments can choose to apply other provisions with modifications.

Concept with Example - Subsection 2:

Concept 1: Law Does Not Apply in Nagaland
Most parts of this law will not work in the State of Nagaland.
• Example: If a new school rule says 'all students must wear ties', but this rule doesn't apply to Class 12 students, similarly most BNSS rules don't apply in Nagaland.

Concept 2: Law Does Not Apply in Tribal Areas
Most parts of this law will not work in certain tribal areas.
• Example: Like some traffic rules don't apply inside a military area, most BNSS rules don't apply in specific tribal areas.

Concept 3: Exception - Three Chapters Apply Everywhere
But three chapters (Chapter 9, Chapter 11, and Chapter 12) WILL work in Nagaland and tribal areas.
• Example: Even though Class 12 is exempt from the tie rule, they still must follow the 'no phone' rule. Similarly, Chapters 9, 11, 12 apply everywhere.

Concept 4: State Government's Special Power
The State Government has a special power - it can decide to use other parts of this law in Nagaland or tribal areas if it wants.
• Example: Like a principal can decide to apply certain school rules to the hostel too, the State Government can choose to apply BNSS rules to these areas.

Concept 5: Official Notification Required
To do this, the State Government must issue an official notification (a formal announcement).
• Example: Just like your school puts up a notice board announcement for new rules, the government must publish an official notification.

Concept 6: Power to Make Local Modifications
The State Government can make small changes to the law to fit local situations when applying it.
• Example: If a school rule says 'wear black shoes' but in a hilly area, the principal allows 'wear boots', similarly, the State can modify rules for local needs.

Concept 7: Changes Must Be Documented
These changes should be mentioned in the notification.
• Example: Like the principal must write 'boots allowed' in the notice, the government must write all changes in their notification.

Subsection-2 states that most provisions of BNSS do not apply to Nagaland and tribal areas, except Chapters IX, XI, and XII. State Governments can notify to apply other provisions with modifications. Example: Like giving special autonomy to certain regions based on their unique needs.

Subsection-2 exists to respect the special constitutional status of Nagaland and tribal areas. These regions have unique cultural, social, and legal traditions that need protection. Example: Like Article 371A which grants special provisions to Nagaland, this subsection ensures their autonomy while maintaining national legal framework.

Subsection-2 applies to: (a) The State of Nagaland, and (b) Tribal areas as defined under the Constitution. These are specially protected regions with distinct legal status. Example: Scheduled Areas under Fifth Schedule and Tribal Areas under Sixth Schedule of the Indian Constitution.

Subsection-2 came into effect with BNSS in 2023. State Governments can issue notifications at any time to apply provisions to these areas. There's no fixed timeline - it depends on when the State Government decides. Example: A State can notify today, tomorrow, or years later based on their assessment.

Subsection-2 identifies: (1) Which areas are exempt: Nagaland and tribal areas. (2) Which chapters DO apply: Chapters IX, XI, and XII. (3) Which provisions DON'T apply: All other chapters. Example: If BNSS has 20 chapters, only 3 automatically apply to these regions; remaining 17 are optional.

Subsection-2 works through a notification system:
Step 1: State Government decides which provisions to apply
Step 2: Issues official notification
Step 3: Can add supplemental or consequential modifications
Step 4: Provisions become applicable as per notification. Example: Like a menu where the State picks what legal provisions suit their region best.

mcq_pool.question: Subsection-2 grants special exemption to which state?
mcq_pool.explanation: Subsection-2 specifically mentions the State of Nagaland as exempt from most BNSS provisions.

mcq_pool.question: Which type of areas are exempt along with Nagaland?
mcq_pool.explanation: Tribal areas are given the same exemption as Nagaland.

mcq_pool.question: How many chapters of BNSS automatically apply to these exempt areas?
mcq_pool.explanation: Three chapters (IX, XI, and XII) automatically apply to Nagaland and tribal areas.

mcq_pool.question: Which chapter is mentioned as automatically applicable?
mcq_pool.explanation: Chapter IX is one of the three chapters that apply to these areas.

mcq_pool.question: Who can notify to apply other BNSS provisions to these areas?
mcq_pool.explanation: The concerned State Government has the power to issue such notifications.

mcq_pool.question: What can State Governments add while applying provisions?
mcq_pool.explanation: State Governments can add supplemental, incidental, or consequential modifications.

mcq_pool.question: The exemption under Subsection-2 applies to how much of Nagaland?
mcq_pool.explanation: The exemption applies to the entire State of Nagaland.

mcq_pool.question: Can State Government apply provisions to only part of the area?
mcq_pool.explanation: State Government can apply to 'whole or part' of the area.

mcq_pool.question: What type of modifications can be made?
mcq_pool.explanation: Supplemental, incidental, or consequential modifications can be made.

mcq_pool.question: Which chapter besides IX and XI also applies automatically?
mcq_pool.explanation: Chapter XII is the third chapter that automatically applies.

mcq_pool.question: The word 'Sanhita' in Subsection-2 refers to:
mcq_pool.explanation: 'This Sanhita' refers to BNSS (Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita).

mcq_pool.question: What must State Government issue to apply provisions?
mcq_pool.explanation: State Government must issue a notification.

mcq_pool.question: Are all BNSS provisions exempt for these areas?
mcq_pool.explanation: No, Chapters IX, XI, and XII automatically apply; only other provisions are exempt.

mcq_pool.question: The exemption is based on what factor?
mcq_pool.explanation: The exemption recognizes the special constitutional and cultural status of these areas.

mcq_pool.question: Can Central Government apply provisions to these areas?
mcq_pool.explanation: Only the concerned State Government can issue such notifications.

mcq_pool.question: What does 'supplemental modifications' mean?
mcq_pool.explanation: Supplemental means additional provisions that supplement the main law.

mcq_pool.question: Which subsection deals with exemptions?
mcq_pool.explanation: Subsection-2 of Section-1 deals with exemptions for Nagaland and tribal areas.

mcq_pool.question: The provisions 'other than' which chapters are exempt?
mcq_pool.explanation: Provisions 'other than' Chapters IX, XI, XII are exempt.

mcq_pool.question: How is the exemption implemented?
mcq_pool.explanation: The exemption is automatic by default; State must notify to apply provisions.

mcq_pool.question: What is the main purpose of Subsection-2?
mcq_pool.explanation: The main purpose is to grant exemptions to special areas while allowing flexibility.

truefalse_pool.statement: Subsection-2 exempts Nagaland from most BNSS provisions.
truefalse_pool.explanation: This is correct. Most provisions do not apply to Nagaland.

truefalse_pool.statement: All provisions of BNSS apply to tribal areas.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. Most provisions do not apply; only Chapters IX, XI, XII apply automatically.

truefalse_pool.statement: Chapter IX applies to Nagaland and tribal areas.
truefalse_pool.explanation: Correct. Chapter IX is one of the three chapters that automatically apply.

truefalse_pool.statement: Only Central Government can notify to apply provisions to these areas.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. The concerned State Government has this power.

truefalse_pool.statement: State Government can make modifications while applying provisions.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. They can make supplemental, incidental, or consequential modifications.

truefalse_pool.statement: Chapter XI does not apply to tribal areas.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. Chapter XI is one of the three chapters that automatically apply.

truefalse_pool.statement: The exemption applies to the entire State of Nagaland.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. The exemption covers the whole State of Nagaland.

truefalse_pool.statement: Chapter XII is exempt from applying to these areas.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. Chapter XII is one of the three chapters that do apply.

truefalse_pool.statement: State Government must apply provisions to the whole area only.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. They can apply to 'whole or part' of the area.

truefalse_pool.statement: Tribal areas have the same exemption status as Nagaland.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. Both are treated similarly under Subsection-2.

truefalse_pool.statement: No chapters of BNSS apply to Nagaland by default.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. Three chapters (IX, XI, XII) apply by default.

truefalse_pool.statement: Notification is required to apply exempt provisions.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. State Government must issue a notification.

truefalse_pool.statement: Subsection-2 is about the law's name.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. Subsection-1 is about the name; Subsection-2 is about exemptions.

truefalse_pool.statement: The exemption recognizes special status of certain areas.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. It respects the unique constitutional status of these regions.

truefalse_pool.statement: State Government cannot modify BNSS provisions while applying.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. They can make specified modifications.

truefalse_pool.statement: Subsection-2 mentions three specific chapters.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. Chapters IX, XI, and XII are specifically mentioned.

truefalse_pool.statement: Urban areas get the same exemption as tribal areas.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. Only tribal areas and Nagaland get this exemption.

truefalse_pool.statement: The exemption is permanent and cannot be changed.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. State Government can notify to apply provisions anytime.

truefalse_pool.statement: Consequential modifications can be specified in the notification.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. The notification can include such modifications.

truefalse_pool.statement: Subsection-2 appears in Section-1 of BNSS.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. It is Subsection-2 of Section-1.

fillblank_pool.question: Subsection-2 grants exemption to __________ and tribal areas.
Only Chapters IX, XI, and __________ apply automatically to these areas.
The concerned __________ Government can notify to apply other provisions.
State Government must issue a __________ to apply provisions.
Provisions can be applied with supplemental, incidental, or __________ modifications.
Chapter __________ is one of the three that automatically apply.
State Government can apply provisions to whole or __________ of the area.
The exemption is for the State of __________ and tribal areas.
Most provisions of BNSS do not __________ to these exempt areas.
__________ modifications can be specified in the notification.
Besides Nagaland, __________ areas also get exemption.
Chapter XI and XII along with Chapter __________ apply automatically.
Subsection-__________ deals with exemptions for special areas.
The provisions 'other than' Chapters IX, XI, XII __________ not apply.
State Government has the power to apply __________ provisions.
Modifications must be __________ in the notification.
The exemption recognizes the __________ status of these regions.
Provisions relating to three chapters __________ apply.
State Government can apply provisions as the __________ may be.
The concerned __________ Government means the State Government of that area.

word_arrangement_pool.correct: The provisions of this Sanhita shall not apply to Nagaland.
State Government may by notification apply such provisions.
Chapters IX, XI and XII apply automatically.

content.text:
Explanation to Subsection-2: Definition of Tribal Areas

• Defines what 'tribal areas' means for the purpose of Subsection-2.
• Refers to territories included in Assam's tribal areas as of January 21, 1972.
• Excludes the municipality of Shillong from this definition.
• Based on Paragraph 20 of the Sixth Schedule to the Constitution.

Explanation - Meaning of 'Tribal Areas'

1. The term 'tribal areas' has a specific meaning in this section.
Example: Just like 'minor' means a person below 18 years, 'tribal areas' has a fixed legal meaning, not just any tribal village.

2. It means those areas that were part of Assam's tribal regions before January 21, 1972.
Example: Like saying 'old currency' means notes printed before 2016, 'tribal areas' means specific regions that existed before a particular date.

3. These areas are mentioned in paragraph 20 of the Sixth Schedule of the Indian Constitution.
Example: Just like your roll number is written in the school register, these areas are officially listed in the Constitution's Sixth Schedule.

4. However, the city area of Shillong municipality is NOT included in 'tribal areas'.
Example: Like saying 'all students get fee waiver except monitors', here all tribal areas are included except Shillong city.

The Explanation states: 'Tribal areas' means the territories which were part of Assam's tribal areas immediately before January 21, 1972, as mentioned in Paragraph 20 of the Sixth Schedule to the Constitution, except areas within Shillong municipality. Example: Like defining a specific geographic region using a historical reference date.

This Explanation exists to provide legal clarity on which areas qualify as 'tribal areas' under Subsection-2. It prevents confusion by fixing a specific date (January 21, 1972) and constitutional reference. Example: Like defining 'minor' as 'person below 18 years' - it removes ambiguity about who qualifies for special provisions.

The Explanation applies to territories that were: (a) Part of Assam's tribal areas before January 21, 1972, (b) Mentioned in Paragraph 20 of Sixth Schedule, and (c) NOT within Shillong municipality limits. Example: Areas like parts of Meghalaya that were tribal areas of Assam before 1972, excluding Shillong city.

The Explanation uses January 21, 1972 as the cut-off date. This is historically significant because it was when Meghalaya became a full state. Territories included as tribal areas 'immediately before' this date qualify. Example: If an area was tribal area on January 20, 1972, it qualifies; if designated after January 21, 1972, it doesn't.

The Explanation identifies: (1) Which areas qualify: Former Assam tribal areas as of Jan 21, 1972. (2) Which constitutional provision: Paragraph 20 of Sixth Schedule. (3) Which areas are excluded: Shillong municipality. Example: Of all tribal areas, only those meeting these three criteria qualify for Subsection-2 exemption.

The Explanation works by establishing three criteria:
Step 1: Check if area was tribal area of Assam
Step 2: Verify status immediately before Jan 21, 1972
Step 3: Confirm it's referenced in Sixth Schedule Para 20
Step 4: Ensure it's NOT within Shillong municipality
All four must be satisfied. Example: Like a checklist - only areas meeting all conditions qualify as 'tribal areas' under BNSS.

mcq_pool.question: The Explanation defines which term?
mcq_pool.explanation: The Explanation specifically defines 'tribal areas'.

mcq_pool.question: What is the reference date mentioned in the Explanation?
mcq_pool.explanation: January 21, 1972 is the specific date mentioned.

mcq_pool.question: Which state's tribal areas are referenced?
mcq_pool.explanation: The Explanation refers to tribal areas of Assam.

mcq_pool.question: Which municipality is specifically excluded?
mcq_pool.explanation: Shillong municipality is explicitly excluded from the definition.

mcq_pool.question: Which constitutional schedule is referenced?
mcq_pool.explanation: The Sixth Schedule to the Constitution is referenced.

mcq_pool.question: Which paragraph of the Sixth Schedule is mentioned?
mcq_pool.explanation: Paragraph 20 of the Sixth Schedule is specifically mentioned.

mcq_pool.question: The territories must have been tribal areas when?
mcq_pool.explanation: They must have been tribal areas 'immediately before' January 21, 1972.

mcq_pool.question: What type of clause is this?
mcq_pool.explanation: This is an Explanation clause that defines a term.

mcq_pool.question: Areas within Shillong municipality are:
mcq_pool.explanation: Areas within Shillong municipality are explicitly excluded.

mcq_pool.question: The Explanation is attached to which subsection?
mcq_pool.explanation: It's the Explanation to Subsection-2.

mcq_pool.question: Why is January 21, 1972 significant?
mcq_pool.explanation: This was when Meghalaya became a full-fledged state.

mcq_pool.question: The definition applies to which section?
mcq_pool.explanation: The Explanation says 'In this section', meaning it applies to this section only.

mcq_pool.question: What does the Explanation clarify?
mcq_pool.explanation: It clarifies the meaning of 'tribal areas'.

mcq_pool.question: The Explanation refers to territories of:
mcq_pool.explanation: It specifically refers to certain Assam tribal areas as of 1972.

mcq_pool.question: Which document is the ultimate reference?
mcq_pool.explanation: The Constitution (Sixth Schedule) is the ultimate reference.

mcq_pool.question: The phrase 'immediately before' means:
mcq_pool.explanation: 'Immediately before' means just before the specified date.

mcq_pool.question: How many conditions must be met for an area to qualify?
mcq_pool.explanation: Four conditions: Assam tribal area, before Jan 21 1972, Sixth Schedule Para 20, not Shillong.

mcq_pool.question: The local limits mentioned refer to:
mcq_pool.explanation: 'Local limits' refers specifically to Shillong municipality boundaries.

mcq_pool.question: The Explanation uses which type of definition?
mcq_pool.explanation: It uses a specific definition with an exact date reference.

mcq_pool.question: Who referred to the tribal areas originally?
mcq_pool.explanation: The Constitution (Sixth Schedule) originally referred to these tribal areas.

truefalse_pool.statement: The Explanation defines 'tribal areas'.
truefalse_pool.explanation: Yes, this is the purpose of the Explanation.

truefalse_pool.statement: The reference date is January 21, 1973.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. The date is January 21, 1972.

truefalse_pool.statement: Shillong municipality is included in 'tribal areas'.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. Shillong municipality is explicitly excluded.

truefalse_pool.statement: The Explanation refers to the Sixth Schedule.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. It refers to Paragraph 20 of the Sixth Schedule.

truefalse_pool.statement: Tribal areas of Meghalaya are referenced.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. It refers to tribal areas of Assam (as of 1972).

truefalse_pool.statement: Paragraph 20 of Sixth Schedule is mentioned.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. This is specifically referenced.

truefalse_pool.statement: The Explanation applies to the entire BNSS.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. It says 'In this section', meaning only Section 1.

truefalse_pool.statement: January 21, 1972 was when Meghalaya became a state.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. This is the historical significance of the date.

truefalse_pool.statement: All tribal areas of India are covered.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. Only specific Assam tribal areas from 1972 are covered.

truefalse_pool.statement: The Explanation provides legal clarity.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. It clarifies what 'tribal areas' means in this context.

truefalse_pool.statement: The territories must have been tribal areas after 1972.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. They must have been tribal areas 'immediately before' 1972.

truefalse_pool.statement: The Constitution is the ultimate reference.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. The Sixth Schedule to the Constitution is referenced.

truefalse_pool.statement: Shillong was excluded because it's urban.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. Municipality areas are excluded from tribal area definition.

truefalse_pool.statement: This is an Explanation clause.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. It's formally labeled as 'Explanation'.

truefalse_pool.statement: The Explanation has no legal significance.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. Explanations are legally significant definitional clauses.

truefalse_pool.statement: 'Immediately before' means just before the date.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. It means right before January 21, 1972.

truefalse_pool.statement: The Explanation defines 'State Government'.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. It defines 'tribal areas', not 'State Government'.

truefalse_pool.statement: Four conditions must be met for an area to qualify.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. Assam area, before Jan 21 1972, Sixth Schedule, not Shillong.

truefalse_pool.statement: The Explanation is attached to Subsection-1.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. It's attached to Subsection-2.

truefalse_pool.statement: The definition uses a historical cut-off date.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. January 21, 1972 is used as the historical reference point.

fillblank_pool.question: The Explanation defines the term '__________ areas'.
The reference date is January __________, 1972.

word_arrangement_pool.correct: Explanation: In this section, tribal areas means
immediately before the 21st day of January, 1972
within the local limits of the municipality of Shillong

content.text:
Subsection-3: Date of Commencement

• This law comes into force on the date notified by Central Government.
• The notification must be published in the Official Gazette.
• Different provisions may come into force on different dates.
• Actual enforcement date: 1st July, 2024 (with one exception).

Sub-section (3) - When This Law Started Working

1. This law did not start immediately after being passed.
Example: Like when Parliament passes a budget in February but it starts from April, this law also had a gap between passing and starting.

2. It started working on a date chosen by the Central Government.
Example: Like your summer vacation dates are decided by your school principal, the starting date of this law was decided by the Central Government.

3. The Central Government had to announce this date through a notification in the Official Gazette (Government's official publication).
Example: Just like important school announcements come in the school diary, government announcements come in the Official Gazette.

Subsection-3 states: This law shall come into force on the date appointed by Central Government through official notification in the Gazette. The actual date notified was 1st July, 2024. Example: Like announcing 'School will start from Monday' - this subsection announces when the law officially begins.

Subsection-3 exists because laws need a clear start date for implementation. It allows time for preparation: training officials, setting up systems, and informing the public. Example: Like giving advance notice before new traffic rules - authorities need time to prepare before enforcing the law.

Subsection-3 applies throughout India where BNSS is applicable (except exempt areas under Subsection-2). The notification is published in the Official Gazette of India. Example: The commencement date is uniform across all non-exempt territories of India.

Subsection-3 became relevant on 23rd February, 2024 when the notification was issued. The law came into force on 1st July, 2024. Timeline: Law passed in 2023 → Notification issued 23-Feb-2024 → Enforcement began 01-Jul-2024. Example: Four months between notification and actual implementation.

Subsection-3 is the commencement clause - the provision that activates the law. It is the third and final subsection of Section 1. Exception: Provisions related to Section 106(2) in First Schedule had different timing. Example: 99% of BNSS started on 1st July 2024; one specific provision had separate timing.

Subsection-3 works through this mechanism:
Step 1: Central Government decides readiness date
Step 2: Issues notification (S.O. 848(E) dated 23-Feb-2024)
Step 3: Publishes in Official Gazette
Step 4: Law becomes enforceable on appointed date (01-Jul-2024). Example: Like flipping a switch - one specific moment when the law 'turns on'.

mcq_pool.question: Who appoints the date for BNSS to come into force?
mcq_pool.explanation: Central Government has the power to appoint the commencement date.

mcq_pool.question: Where must the commencement notification be published?
mcq_pool.explanation: The notification must be published in the Official Gazette.

mcq_pool.question: On what date did BNSS come into force?
mcq_pool.explanation: BNSS came into force on 1st July, 2024.

mcq_pool.question: When was the commencement notification issued?
mcq_pool.explanation: The notification was issued on 23rd February, 2024.

mcq_pool.question: What is the notification number for commencement?
mcq_pool.explanation: The notification number is S.O. 848(E).

mcq_pool.question: Which section had an exception in commencement?
mcq_pool.explanation: Section 106(2) related provisions in First Schedule had an exception.

mcq_pool.question: In which Schedule was the exception mentioned?
mcq_pool.explanation: The exception was in the First Schedule.

mcq_pool.question: What does 'come into force' mean?
mcq_pool.explanation: 'Come into force' means the law becomes legally enforceable.

mcq_pool.question: The commencement date is appointed by which method?
mcq_pool.explanation: It is appointed by official notification.

mcq_pool.question: Can different provisions come into force on different dates?
mcq_pool.explanation: Yes, different provisions can have different commencement dates (as shown by the exception).

mcq_pool.question: Which subsection deals with commencement?
mcq_pool.explanation: Subsection-3 deals with the date of commencement.

mcq_pool.question: In which year did BNSS come into force?
mcq_pool.explanation: BNSS came into force in 2024.

mcq_pool.question: The notification was published in which part of Gazette?
mcq_pool.explanation: It was published in Part II, section 3(ii) of the Gazette.

mcq_pool.question: What type of Gazette was used?
mcq_pool.explanation: The Gazette of India, Extraordinary was used.

mcq_pool.question: How many months between notification and enforcement?
mcq_pool.explanation: About 4 months elapsed (23rd Feb to 1st July).

mcq_pool.question: The word 'appoint' in subsection-3 means:
mcq_pool.explanation: 'Appoint' here means to fix or decide upon a date.

mcq_pool.question: What does 'shall come into force' indicate?
mcq_pool.explanation: 'Shall' indicates a mandatory future action.

mcq_pool.question: The exception clause used which punctuation?
mcq_pool.explanation: Square brackets [ ] were used for the exception.

mcq_pool.question: Which month did BNSS become operational?
mcq_pool.explanation: BNSS became operational in July 2024.

mcq_pool.question: The commencement applies to how much of BNSS?
mcq_pool.explanation: Almost all provisions came into force except Section 106(2) related entries.

truefalse_pool.statement: Central Government appoints the commencement date of BNSS.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. Central Government has this power under Subsection-3.

truefalse_pool.statement: BNSS came into force on 1st January, 2024.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. It came into force on 1st July, 2024.

truefalse_pool.statement: The notification must be published in the Official Gazette.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. This is a mandatory requirement.

truefalse_pool.statement: All provisions of BNSS came into force on the same date.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. Provisions related to Section 106(2) in First Schedule had an exception.

truefalse_pool.statement: The commencement notification was issued on 23rd February, 2024.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. This is the date mentioned in the footnote.

truefalse_pool.statement: State Governments appoint the commencement date.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. Only Central Government has this power.

truefalse_pool.statement: The notification number is S.O. 848(E).
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. This is the correct notification number.

truefalse_pool.statement: BNSS came into force in 2023.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. It came into force in 2024, though enacted in 2023.

truefalse_pool.statement: Subsection-3 is about the law's title.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. Subsection-1 is about title; Subsection-3 is about commencement.

truefalse_pool.statement: The exception related to Section 106(2) in the First Schedule.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. This is specifically mentioned in the footnote.

truefalse_pool.statement: No notification is needed for BNSS to come into force.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. A notification in the Official Gazette is mandatory.

truefalse_pool.statement: The law came into force immediately after being passed.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. There was a gap between enactment (2023) and enforcement (July 2024).

truefalse_pool.statement: 'Come into force' means the law becomes enforceable.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. This is the correct legal meaning.

truefalse_pool.statement: The notification was published in an Extraordinary Gazette.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. It was in the Gazette of India, Extraordinary.

truefalse_pool.statement: Subsection-3 is the last subsection of Section 1.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. It is the third and final subsection.

truefalse_pool.statement: Different provisions can have different commencement dates.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. The exception proves this is possible.

truefalse_pool.statement: The commencement date was 23rd February, 2024.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. That was the notification date; commencement was 1st July, 2024.

truefalse_pool.statement: The notification allows time for implementation preparation.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. The gap between notification and enforcement allows preparation time.

truefalse_pool.statement: BNSS became operational in July 2024.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. It came into force on 1st July, 2024.

truefalse_pool.statement: The commencement provision is in Subsection-2.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. It is in Subsection-3.

fillblank_pool.question: This law shall come into force on such date as the __________ Government may appoint.
The date must be appointed by notification in the Official __________.
BNSS came into force on __________ July, 2024.
The commencement notification was issued on 23rd __________, 2024.
The notification number was S.O. __________(E).
The exception related to Section __________(2) in the First Schedule.
The exception was in the __________ Schedule.

Almost all provisions came into force __________ one exception.

The enforcement date was in the month of __________.

word_arrangement_pool.correct: It shall come into force on such date as appointed.
Central Government may appoint the date by notification.
BNSS came into force on 1st July 2024.

content.text:
Footnote-1: Commencement Notification Details

• Notification No.: S.O. 848(E)
• Date of Notification: 23rd February, 2024
• Date of Enforcement: 1st July, 2024
• Exception: Provisions related to Section 106(2) in First Schedule
• Published in: Gazette of India, Extraordinary, Part II, sec. 3(ii)

Footnote - Actual Starting Date

1. The Central Government announced the starting date through notification number S.O. 848(E).
Example: Like your exam admit card has a number (like 2024/EXAM/12345), this notification has a number: S.O. 848(E).

2. This notification was issued on February 23, 2024.
Example: Like your exam date sheet is released on a specific date, this notification came out on February 23, 2024.

3. According to this notification, the law came into force on July 1, 2024.
Example: Like school reopening after summer vacation on July 1st, this law started working from July 1, 2024.

4. However, one part was kept out - the provisions related to Section 106(2) in the First Schedule did not start on this date.
Example: Like school reopens on July 1st but the science lab opens a week later, most of BNSS started on July 1st but Section 106(2) didn't start then.

5. This notification was published in the Gazette of India, Extraordinary edition, Part II, Section 3(ii).
Example: Like important news comes in a special edition newspaper, this notification was published in a special 'Extraordinary' edition of the government's official publication, in a specific section (Part II, Section 3(ii)).

Footnote-1 provides the specific details of how and when BNSS came into force. It references notification S.O. 848(E) dated 23rd February 2024, which appointed 1st July 2024 as the enforcement date, with one exception. Example: Like fine print that gives the complete reference details for verification.

Footnote-1 exists to provide official documentation and verification details. Legal documents need precise references so anyone can verify the information in official records. Example: Like citing sources in research - it allows readers to check the original notification in the Gazette.

Footnote-1 appears at the bottom of Section 1, linked to Subsection-3. The actual notification can be found in the Gazette of India, Extraordinary, Part II, section 3(ii). Example: Physical location: bottom of page; Reference location: Official Gazette archives.

Footnote-1 references two key dates: Notification issued on 23rd February 2024, and enforcement began on 1st July 2024. Timeline: Law enacted 2023 → Notification Feb 2024 → Enforcement July 2024. Example: About 4 months gap for implementation preparation.

Footnote-1 is the first (and only) footnote to Section 1. It identifies: (1) Which notification: S.O. 848(E), (2) Which exception: Section 106(2) in First Schedule, (3) Which publication: Gazette of India, Extraordinary. Example: Among all documentation, this footnote pinpoints the exact official reference.

Footnote-1 works as a documentation reference:
Step 1: Links to Subsection-3's date mention
Step 2: Provides notification number (S.O. 848(E))
Step 3: States exact dates (issued 23-Feb, effective 1-Jul)
Step 4: Notes exception in square brackets
Step 5: Gives Gazette publication details. Example: Like a detailed citation that allows verification of every claim.

mcq_pool.question: What is the notification number mentioned in Footnote-1?
mcq_pool.explanation: The notification number is S.O. 848(E).

mcq_pool.question: On which date was the notification issued?
mcq_pool.explanation: The notification was issued on 23rd February, 2024.

mcq_pool.question: What date did BNSS come into force according to the footnote?
mcq_pool.explanation: BNSS came into force on 1st July, 2024.

mcq_pool.question: Which section's provisions had an exception?
mcq_pool.explanation: Section 106(2) related provisions had an exception.

mcq_pool.question: In which schedule was the exception?
mcq_pool.explanation: The exception was in the First Schedule.

mcq_pool.question: Where was the notification published?
mcq_pool.explanation: It was published in the Gazette of India.

mcq_pool.question: What type of Gazette was used?
mcq_pool.explanation: The Gazette of India, Extraordinary was used.

mcq_pool.question: In which part of the Gazette was it published?
mcq_pool.explanation: It was published in Part II, section 3(ii).

mcq_pool.question: The exception is marked with which punctuation?
mcq_pool.explanation: The exception is marked with square brackets [ ].

mcq_pool.question: What does 'vide' mean in the footnote?
mcq_pool.explanation: 'Vide' is a Latin term meaning 'see' or 'refer to'.

mcq_pool.question: Which year is mentioned in the footnote?
mcq_pool.explanation: The year 2024 is mentioned for both notification and enforcement dates.

mcq_pool.question: What is the purpose of Footnote-1?
mcq_pool.explanation: The footnote provides official reference and documentation details.

mcq_pool.question: The notification number starts with:
mcq_pool.explanation: The notification starts with S.O. (Statutory Order).

mcq_pool.question: How many days are mentioned in the footnote date?
mcq_pool.explanation: Both 1st (July) and 23rd (February) are mentioned.

mcq_pool.question: The footnote is linked to which subsection?
mcq_pool.explanation: Footnote-1 is linked to Subsection-3.

mcq_pool.question: What does S.O. likely stand for?
mcq_pool.explanation: S.O. stands for Statutory Order.

mcq_pool.question: The exception clause is about provisions relating to:
mcq_pool.explanation: The exception relates to Section 106(2).

mcq_pool.question: Which month was the notification issued?
mcq_pool.explanation: The notification was issued in February.

mcq_pool.question: Which month did enforcement begin?
mcq_pool.explanation: Enforcement began in July.

mcq_pool.question: The footnote provides details for:
mcq_pool.explanation: The footnote provides commencement notification details.

truefalse_pool.statement: Footnote-1 mentions notification number S.O. 848(E).
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. This is the correct notification number.

truefalse_pool.statement: The notification was issued on 1st July, 2024.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. It was issued on 23rd February, 2024; enforcement was on 1st July.

truefalse_pool.statement: BNSS came into force on 1st July, 2024.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. This is the enforcement date mentioned in the footnote.

truefalse_pool.statement: All provisions of BNSS came into force on 1st July, 2024.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. Provisions related to Section 106(2) in First Schedule were excepted.

truefalse_pool.statement: The notification was published in the Gazette of India, Extraordinary.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. This is the correct publication.

truefalse_pool.statement: The exception relates to Section 107(2).
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. The exception relates to Section 106(2).

truefalse_pool.statement: The footnote is linked to Subsection-3.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. Footnote-1 provides details for the date mentioned in Subsection-3.

truefalse_pool.statement: The exception was in the Second Schedule.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. It was in the First Schedule.

truefalse_pool.statement: The notification was published in Part II, sec. 3(ii) of the Gazette.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. This is the correct Gazette section.

truefalse_pool.statement: The notification number contains the letter E in brackets.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. The notification is S.O. 848(E).

truefalse_pool.statement: The notification date and enforcement date are the same.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. Notification was on 23rd Feb; enforcement on 1st July.

truefalse_pool.statement: 'Vide' means 'see' or 'refer to'.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. 'Vide' is a Latin term meaning 'see'.

truefalse_pool.statement: The exception is marked with square brackets.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. Square brackets [ ] are used for the exception.

truefalse_pool.statement: The footnote appears at the top of Section 1.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. Footnotes appear at the bottom.

truefalse_pool.statement: Both February and July dates are in 2024.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. Both dates fall in the year 2024.

truefalse_pool.statement: The footnote provides verification details.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. It allows anyone to verify the notification in official records.

truefalse_pool.statement: S.O. stands for Special Order.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. S.O. stands for Statutory Order.

truefalse_pool.statement: About 4 months elapsed between notification and enforcement.
truefalse_pool.explanation: True. From 23rd February to 1st July is about 4 months.

truefalse_pool.statement: The footnote mentions multiple notification numbers.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. Only one notification number (S.O. 848(E)) is mentioned.

truefalse_pool.statement: The Gazette used was an ordinary edition.
truefalse_pool.explanation: False. It was an Extraordinary edition of the Gazette.

fillblank_pool.question: The notification number is S.O. __________(E).
The notification was dated __________day of February, 2024.
BNSS came into force on __________ July, 2024.
The exception relates to Section __________(2).
The exception was in the __________ Schedule.
The notification was published in the Gazette of India, __________.
It was published in Part __________, sec. 3(ii).
The Latin word __________ means 'see' or 'refer to'.
The exception is marked with __________ brackets.
S.O. stands for __________ Order.
The notification was issued in the month of __________.
The enforcement began in the month of __________.
Both dates mentioned are in the year __________.
Footnote-1 is linked to Subsection-__________.
The notification provides __________ details.
The notification was published in the __________ Gazette.
See Gazette of India means __________ notification number S.O. 848(E).
The exception clause uses the word '__________' to indicate the exception.
About __________ months passed between notification and enforcement.
The entry in the First Schedule relates to Section 106(__________)

word_arrangement_pool.correct: BNSS came into force on 1st July 2024.
Except provisions relating to Section 106(2) in First Schedule.
